text: data mining and knowledge discovery have revolutionized the way that people interact with information on
the web if i want to find pages related to a particular topic
i can use a search engine like google that minds the textual content of web pages
if i want to find new movies that i'm likely to enjoy i can use the netflix recommender system
which mines the ratings people give to films and tv shows that they watch
but there are some questions that traditional content-based data mining and knowledge discovery
can't answer in particular understanding information and understanding how that information is
presented are two fundamentally different tasks so if i want to find inspiration when
i'm building a web page or understand if a particular page is designed well
or get suggestions for how to make my page look better google isn't going to be much help
these problems have all been studied in the literature and different authors have approached them
in different ways but there's a single underlying question here if data mining and knowledge discovery
have proven so useful in understanding information content on the web why can't we use the same
tools and techniques to study design answering this question
is precisely the subject of my thesis in particular i want to i introduce
website geist a scalable software platform for design mining the web bringing data
mining and knowledge discovery techniques to web design for the very first time when
you think about it the web is the largest repository of design knowledge in human history
and it presents an opportunity to learn about design practice on a truly massive scale every
single page provides a concrete example of visual problem solving and human
creativity and aesthetics and there are billions of pages to draw from
the goal of website geist is to give us a way to make sense of all of this design data
the premise of design mining is to make it easy for users to quickly and easily find relevant design
information understand that information by distilling general principles and recognizing design patterns
and then leverage that understanding to power design-driven web applications
for instance by automatically retargeting content between different layouts and styles or
making a static page responsive for mobile and tablet display
in this talk we'll explore how design mining can be used to solve all of these problems but first i'll
describe the development of the website geist architecture and the principles motivating its
construction website guys is fundamentally different
than content-based web crawlers that statically analyze a page's source to mine web design
website guys renders each page in the canonical view and then stores all of the resources and
properties that contribute to the page's visual appearance to give
users a way to interact with page designs the platform computes a visual segmentation of each page
along with a set of descriptive features for every element in those segmentations
in most previous work studying the visual composition of the web a page is the fundamental unit of design
website geist and contrast operates on individual page elements allowing users and applications to
interact with data the design data at multiple scales and we'll see how important this
property is later on in the talk to segment pages into design elements
website guys leverages the document object model tree for many pages the dom provides a close
approximation to the page's visual hierarchy but it's not a perfect representation
many notes in the dom don't contribute to the rendered appearance of a page and there can be many different ways to
use the dom to implement any particular visual design website guys canonicalizes
the dom by identifying the elements that contribute to a page's visual appearance
and then reshuffling the hierarchy so that parent-child relationships in the dom match visual containment on
the page this generates a structured visual representation
of designs that are directly comparable between pages
on top of this segmentation website guys computes a set of descriptive features for every page
element which users and application developers can leverage these features comprise all the design
properties we can think of to measure including the render time html and css
properties computed by the layout engine a collection of computer vision features
such as just scene descriptors and a set of high level structural properties relating to the page
segmentation itself the website guys architecture is based
on four design principles the first is consistency
the web is dynamic but machine learning applications expect data to remain
unchanged between accesses website guys therefore store static snapshots
of page designs the second is completeness
websites is intended to be a general design mining platform if an application needs a particular
piece of data website guys should provide it thus website
saves all the resources and properties that contribute to a page's visual
design the third is scalability
design mining applications need to be performant with millions or even billions of of page elements
websites replicates data in multiple formats for efficient retrieval in a wide variety of use cases
and the last is extensibility to make it easy to build design mining
applications on top of website geist in any programming language or development environment
users interact with the platform through a restful api that delivers data using json
the website guys api is optimized for three common use cases
direct or random access to specific design properties streaming access to retrieve large
swaths of the repository for instance for machine learning applications and
query-based access to allow for filtering based on design properties this
querying language the squaring interface is exposed via
a custom query language called dql or for design query language which
transparently converts user requests into sql or query language to abstract
away the underlying data store so that developers can access design data
without worrying about how or where that data is stored in the repository
the website guys data set is an ongoing project but we see that the initial crawl with
pages from the alexa top 500 the webby awards gallery and popular design blogs we crawl pages
in a breath first order and limit downloads to 10 pages per domain to ensure a diverse diverse repository
we also spoof http headers and request both mobile and tablet versions of pages
so that we can understand how design chain designs change across form factors
currently the website guys data set consists of around 100 000 web pages which corresponds to
about 150 million individual dom nodes or about 15 million
visual design elements
now let's turn our attention to the problems that design mining can help us solve
one of the most universal problems faced by designers is finding inspiration examples
help developers by illustrating the space of possible design solutions
and how to implement those possibilities but where are designers supposed to turn
when they need to find material frequently they rely on hand curated galleries of
pages that have been painstakingly collected over time for for instance here's an article on
a popular design blog showing a collection of 40 horizontal web pages pages
that scroll left to right instead of up and down just just out of curiosity how many
people in this room have actually seen horizontal scrolling web pages
okay so a few um but you can see now why this sort of
curation uh can be invaluable to designers even though you know building these galleries
is a manual time consuming process with website guys
designers can dynamically curate design galleries in a matter of seconds here's a simple query written in dql
which searches the repository for pages with screenshots that have an aspect ratio greater than
10 that is pages that are 10 times wider than they are tall
and here's what we get when we execute the query now there's two important takeaways from
this example the first is the ease with which design mining can automate
tasks that are difficult or laborious for people and the second is the importance of
working with design data at scale out of the hundred thousand
pages only 68 or a little less than .07 percent of the archive
match the query so to find even a single example of horizontal scrolling
page to find a single example of a horizontal scrolling page we need at least 1500 pages in the in
the repository and the point here is that you really need scale to get at the long tail of
design where a lot of this creativity is clustered
another example of how this kind of curation can be useful is the is the canvas tag the w3c
introduced the canvas tag in html5 and the spec described it as a
general purpose scriptable graphics container and when it was first proposed there was
a lot of confusion over what this really meant if you you know search google to find
more information what you end up with are a lot of tutorials like this one which give you useful information but
provide little insight into how the tag is actually used in design
with website guys we can find thousands of examples of canvas elements
deployed in real pages and start and start to develop insight about how the tag is actually
used you know animations graphs rounded corners and interestingly
enough custom fonts in fact the overwhelming
majority of canvas tags returned by website guys are used to render custom
fonts which is in direct contravention of w3c guidelines
so here design mining has helped us find an instance where prescribed usage differs drastically
from practice the web font standard is so broken and crippled that
designers have found creative workarounds to guarantee that they can control the way their content
is displayed
and another common problem for designers is to be faced with an existing design
and want to find similar alternatives suppose you're about to kick off your
new marketing startup and you want to scout out the competition
the french company milky has a nice website and finding examples of other pages with
similar designs could inform the way you build your brand this is a task that would be difficult
if not impossible to perform using google
but with website guys we can translate some of the high level design properties of the milky
home page into a dql query and search for matching pages in the repository
these results illustrate how similar layouts can be used to express different visual themes and they might
be useful to help guide the design of your startup's web page
now some designers don't want to interact with website guys at the level of code
and people aren't always able to articulate what it is that they like about a design
or what makes a design distinctive but with design mining we can build
applications that allow users to search for inspiration in different ways and if you can switch
to the demo um this demo that i'm going to show you
which is available on our website uh provides the ability to do query by example searches over
pages in the website guys repository
so here's the milky website again but instead of writing a dql query where
we can simply so we can just simply select the page
and then search for similar design elements in the database
this search is powered by a distance metric trained over the feature descriptors that i described earlier
and uses locality sensitive hashing to make nearest neighbor queries in the feature space
run in real time and what's really cool about this interaction is that there are
some pages here um like the dql query we saw before that have large headers
and top navbars but you'll also notice other results that are similar to the query in
different ways so these such as pages with this you know dark light dark striping
that you'll see so you know once a designer has found a page she likes
she can click on it and website guys allows her to close the
loop and inspect the way that the page was implemented to inform the development of new sites
so you can see the html all of the render time css properties
and this is just one example of the kinds of new interactions that design mining can enable can i
switch back thanks
so design mining can also help us understand the relationship between the way a particular page
element is designed and the semantic role of that element in the page's information architecture
html5 was published as a working draft by the w3c
in 2008 more than 10 years after the introduction of ht the html4 standard and
one of the most contentious features of the spec was the inclusion for the for the first time of a set of
purely semantic tags a few of which i've shown here highlighted in green
these tags describe the structural role of the page content but have no effect whatsoever on
how that content is presented or displayed and the contention about whether or not
these elements should be included in the html spec was reflective of the long-standing tension between
application developers who want rich structure and explicit markup in web design
and designers you know who just want their web page to look good
in in particular there's a chicken and egg problem here these kinds of semactics can enable a
whole host of new web applications you know making pages more accessible facilitating retargeting and improving
the performance of machine learning applications but web designers have little direct
incentive to semantify their pages before these applications actually exist so another thing that
design mining can do is help us find a way out of this problem by
bootstrapping structural semantic tags on pages from design data
so we built a crowdsourcing application on top of website geist and used it to collect structural
semantic labels for page elements we asked participants to select the most
important elements on a set of web pages and then to provide descriptors
that explain their role in the page's information architecture through the study we collected 20 000
structural semantic labels for more than a thousand pages
now here are a set of spatial probability distributions from the data we collected each
distribution shows where a particular semantic concept is most likely to appear on a web page
and from these distributions we can see that the visual presentation of page elements
and the structural semantics of those elements are sometimes highly correlated
following this observation we trained a set of off-the-shelf binary svm classifiers on
the full 1700 dimensional website guys feature space
from just the design information without any content analysis at all we can classify page elements like nav
bars and logos with around 90 percent accuracy some concepts like comments are harder
to reliably identify but it seems likely that we can improve
these results in the futures by using more sophisticated machine learning techniques
the larger point however is that we can take these classifiers
and run them over new pages predicting structural semantic tags for pages that
don't already have them and once we've predicted this data we can make it available to developers
to drive new applications for instance making it possible for designers to search for page
elements using semantic keywords
one final scenario in which we can leverage design understanding to enable new interactions is automatic
retargeting a common practice on the web is to adapt
the designs of other pages for new content so here we have an
example of a phd student who built himself a nice website
and then two professors who stole it
usually the way that one goes about this is by copying bits of content and html between pages this can be an
effective way to explore new designs but as we show here it's also a manual
time consuming process that operates at the level of source code and requires significant technical
sophistication and when people transfer content in this
way they are implicitly establishing correspondences between page elements in effect inducing
a mapping between pages so if we could algorithmically reproduce
these mappings we could use them to automatically guide the transfer of content and style
bricolage is an algorithm that uses design mining data to provide one-click retargeting between
web pages given two web pages bricolage
automatically transfers the content from one page into the style and layout
of another at a glance this seems like a difficult
interaction to enable but the key point here is that this is something that
people already do and so we can use design mining techniques to
understand how and then leverage that understanding to build an automated system
to develop this understanding we ran an online study we created a crowdsourcing tool for
people to specify correspondences between pages given a highlighted segment in the left
page participants were asked to indicate the corresponding segment on the right
and this process continued until every segment had been matched
after every fifth match users were prompted to provide a short rationale for their decision
now in the data we collected we found several important patterns first
many participants use the words use words like link menu and image in their submitted
rationales indicating that a lot of matching is based on visual or semantic cues
this pattern is also borne out by the collected mappings people match semantically similar
elements together such as logos navigational bars and search boxes
however not every element in a web page has strong semantics for these elements
we found that people leverage the visual structure of the page to determine where to map them
so one type of structure is ancestry we call it mapping between pages
ancestry preserving if once two nodes are matched their children are matched as well
the mappings collected in our study turn out to be 53 percent ancestry preserving on average
another kind of structure is sibling relationships we call it mapping sibling preserving if
once two notes are matched their siblings are matched as well the mappings collected in our study were
84 sibling preserving on average and we see that supporting these
structural statistics there are many words in the collective rationales that relate to structure
such as layout column and subsection
so this study gives intuition about how to produce human-like mappings
between pages we want a matching algorithm that incorporates both semantic
and structural constraints and can balance between them
since the page segmentations we're using are trees our first strategy was to turn to the
tree matching literature tree matching algorithms define mappings between trees by matching together
similar nodes while simultaneously preserving hierarchical relationships
across the trees but it turns out that the tree matching
formalism is too rigid for mapping between designs tree matching algorithms rigidly enforce
ancestry and this constraint is too restrictive for capturing human mappings
for example if the hero image is here and the logos are matched together
in these two pages tree matching breaks because it's enabled to match the search bars
so we developed an algorithm for flexible tree matching which relaxes this rigid ancestry constraint
we accomplish this by adding sibling and ancestry terms to the tree matching cost
model which makes ancestry and sibling preservation soft constraints and allows the algorithm to balance
between them just to briefly explain the technical
details we formulate flexible tree matching as finding the minimum cost mapping in a
complete bipartite graph the nodes from the two page segmentations form the two sides of the
complete bipartite graph and we define a mapping to be the set of edges from this graph
such that every node in the two trees is covered by precisely one edge
and if we look at the cost model the cost of an edge in this graph is the sum of three terms
a visual cost an ancestry cost and a sibling cost
and we if we look at the visual cost the visual cost is just a weighted euclidean distance between the website guys
feature vectors so the edge that connects the h1 headers
will have a much smaller visual cost than the edge that connects the header
to the image next let's consider the ancestry cost
term suppose you fix an edge between these two container nodes
then the edge matching together two children these two tax blocks will have a smaller
ancestry cost than the edge matching together one child and a sibling so the answer she cost
penalizes edges that fail to preserve ancestry relationships between the page trees
and the sibling class term works in pretty much the same way suppose you fix an edge between the two
headings then the edge matching together two siblings these two text blocks will
have a smaller sibling cost than the edge matching one sibling to a
parent of the node so the sibling cost penalizes edges
that fail to preserve sibling relationships between page trees
it turns out that evaluating the cost model and computing the minimum cost mapping
is mp complete so we use a stochastic approximation algorithm that works by
bounding the edge cost so we pick the edge with the lowest estimated cost
we fix it in the mapping we then remove all the edges incident on its terminal nodes and by pruning
those edges we can update the bounds on the remaining edges and so this process repeats we pick the
best edge prune and update bounce until we converge to a mapping
intuitively you can think of this as first the elements that are semantically
very similar on the page get mapped together and then the ancestry
and sibling cost determine how everything that's left over gets matched and a nice
feature of the flexible tree matching is that we can train the parameters of the
algorithm on the corpus of human mappings that we collected
and we do this by using the generalized perceptron algorithm which is a standard structure prediction
technique and in this way we can learn the cost model that best reproduces human behavior and
subsequently use it to predict predict mappings between any pair of web pages
and in fact this learning works fairly well bricolage is able to reproduce human
mappings with nearly 80 accuracy and we show that this careful
balance between semantic and structural constraints is essential to producing good mappings
if we remove any of the terms from the cost model the predictive power of the algorithm
decreases substantially so once we have bricolage we can now use
it to rapidly prototype alternative designs by taking an existing page
and retargeting that page's content into new styles and layouts
now one of the reasons that retargeting is such an important problem is because the
number of devices on which people view web content is exploding manually
retargeting pages for every possible form factor is already more or less impossible
what's needed are automatic methods that adapt content across devices and design
mining gives us some intuition that it may be possible to develop these techniques in a data-driven way
consider the spatial probability distributions i showed you before for popular web
elements but now let's compare how these distributions change between desktop and mobile pages
some elements like headers look pretty much the same on both desktop and
mobile pages but the distribution for others like sidebars
change in dramatic ways so just from this data it seems reasonable
to hope that we might be able to programmatically understand
the patterns that designers use when they map content across form factors
and we've already made a little progress in this area by demonstrating how bricolage can be
used to retarget between different form factors by training the algorithm
on a set of desktop to mobile mappings these are still you know early results
but we can for instance automatically map this desktop page
into two different mobile layouts and in the future we hope to apply design
mining techniques to this problem with even greater success
as we look to the future it's important to recognize that the vision for design mining is not just
to help us build some particular set of applications
fundamentally what websitegeist affords us is the ability to empirically study
design at scale instead of relying on a set of experts to give us the best
practices for web design we can start building and understanding from data
in a rigorous way and these ideas aren't just restricted to the web
as more and more creative work is done digitally and shared in the cloud we hope that the
lessons we learn and the techniques we develop to answer these questions in web design
can eventually be transferred to other domains particularly in light of all of the
recent work in computer graphics on data driven 3d modeling
and scene understanding and design mining can help us do more
than just build design tools as we start to ask big questions like what makes a
design beautiful we can also hope to better understand how design and utility are related
for instance one question that comes to mind is how google might use design mining to
update their rankings of site quality and trustworthiness
another important observation is that while building more sophisticated tools
is exciting um there's tremendous value to be had from ju from just making design data
more readily accessible to designers designers are already living breathing
data-driven generative models and we know that giving them better access
to the information they care about can make them more productive efficient
and creative and this is fundamentally what design
mining is about bringing scientific rigor and sophisticated analysis
to the study of creativity eventually we'd like to be able to understand why
turning to 1950s hot rods for inspiration in designing shoes was not only a
sensible decision but a beautiful powerful and evocative
one and my hope is that this thesis
takes a first step in this direction

i'm not crying so you can

yeah i mean the issue of quality is possibly like the hardest thing that we haven't like to tackle in

you know the current design data we've mined it's really hard to still extract that so i

yes so you you pointed out fairly early on

well i mean i think right now the web is more it's actually you know people always ask

you know doms to get the visual segmentation and really it's close you know i would there are

that there's no correspondences between like the the hierarchy and the dom and the visual

i think from the last five years what i've learned is having the semantics would just make all of
